importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication reflects the ongoing government shutdown and the urgent need to sustain federal food assistance programs like WIC during funding gaps.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The fiscal year 2026 budget cycle began on October 1, 2025, and the lack of appropriations created a funding lapse that prompted the White House's emergency tariff revenue plan to keep WIC operational.

keyTakeAways: The Trump administration announced it would use Section 32 tariff revenue—normally supporting child nutrition programs—to fund WIC during the government shutdown, shifting from initially proposed Section 232 revenue.
WIC, which serves nearly 7 million pregnant women, new moms, and young children, is at risk of shutting down due to Congress’s failure to pass a fiscal year 2026 spending bill.
The National WIC Association supports efforts to keep WIC running but expresses concern about unclear details: funding amount, state access speed, and duration of support.
Legal experts question the administration’s authority to redirect tariff revenue without congressional appropriation, emphasizing that funds are not legally authorized for such use.
Section 232 tariffs are based on national security grounds and have generated $190 billion in revenue this year; the White House proposed using a portion of these funds for WIC.
WIC provides critical nutrition support including infant formula, baby food, fruits, vegetables, and breastfeeding support; participation has grown due to easier enrollment and rising inflation.
Federal WIC funding is capped, and despite receiving $7.6 billion in FY2025, advocates argue more funding is needed to prevent cuts and ensure no family is turned away.
The House proposes flat funding, while the Senate version allocates $8.2 billion, indicating bipartisan concern over sustainability.
Bipartisan figures like House Speaker Mike Johnson criticized Democrats for political actions that halted government operations and affected vulnerable populations.
The White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt publicly announced the tariff funding plan on X, framing it as a counter to Democratic political behavior.

namedEntities.name: White House
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The executive branch office of the U.S. President
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The White House is central to the announcement of using tariff revenue to fund WIC during the shutdown, demonstrating executive action in response to government funding gaps.

namedEntities.name: Karoline Leavitt
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She publicly announced and justified the tariff revenue plan for WIC, framing it as a response to Democratic-led shutdown politics.

namedEntities.name: Section 32 tariff revenue
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A category of tariff revenue intended to support child nutrition programs
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the specific revenue stream being redirected to fund WIC during the shutdown, highlighting a shift from Section 232 revenue.

namedEntities.name: Section 232 tariffs
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Tariffs imposed on goods for national security reasons
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Initially proposed as a funding source, but later replaced by Section 32 revenue, illustrating policy adjustments in emergency funding.

namedEntities.name: WIC (Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal food assistance program for pregnant women, new mothers, and young children
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The program is central to the article, as its temporary funding crisis during the shutdown prompted the administration's tariff-based solution.

namedEntities.name: National WIC Association
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The advocacy organization representing WIC participants and state agencies
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It expressed both support and skepticism about the tariff funding plan, highlighting concerns about transparency and long-term sustainability.

namedEntities.name: Congress
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The legislative body responsible for budget approvals
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Congress has failed to pass a fiscal year 2026 spending bill, directly causing the funding gap that prompted the White House intervention.

namedEntities.name: House Speaker Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Leader of the U.S. House of Representatives
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He criticized Democrats for political shutdown behavior, linking it directly to the suspension of vital government programs like WIC.

namedEntities.name: Chris Towner
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Policy director at the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He challenged the legality of the White House's use of tariff funds, citing lack of congressional appropriation as a constitutional and legal barrier.

namedEntities.name: U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal agency overseeing agricultural and nutrition programs
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The USDA warned of WIC funding lapses and provided contingency funding and state-level options to mitigate the shutdown impact.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: President of the United States during the second term
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He initiated the tariff policy framework and has been associated with the broader economic and political context of the tariff revenue decisions.

namedEntities.name: Axios
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: News organization that first reported the White House's plan
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The article notes Axios as the first to report the administration's effort, signaling media attention and credibility.

namedEntities.name: Senate minority leader Chuck Schumer
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Leader of the Democratic Party in the U.S. Senate
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is cited by House Speaker Johnson as a political figure whose actions contributed to the shutdown and its consequences for WIC.

namedEntities.name: Fiscal Year 2026
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The U.S. fiscal year starting October 1, 2025
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The period during which the government shutdown occurred and the funding gap for WIC became critical.

namedEntities.name: Tami Luhby and Samantha Waldenberg
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: CNN journalists reporting on the article
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are the reporters who gathered and disseminated the news about the tariff funding proposal and its implications.

namedEntities.name: CNN
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: News network reporting on the article
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It serves as the source and platform for the news coverage of the tariff funding plan and its political and social consequences.

summaryOfNewsArticle: During the ongoing government shutdown in October 2025, the Trump administration announced it would redirect Section 32 tariff revenue—typically used for child nutrition—to fund the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children (WIC), which serves nearly 7 million vulnerable families. This decision was made after Congress failed to pass a fiscal year 2026 spending bill, threatening to shut down WIC operations. While the National WIC Association welcomes the effort to keep the program running, it raises concerns about the amount, timing, and duration of funding. Legal experts question the administration’s authority to use tariff funds without congressional appropriation. The plan was announced by White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt and has drawn bipartisan political attention, with figures like House Speaker Mike Johnson criticizing Democrats for political shutdowns. Despite WIC's long-standing bipartisan support and recent enrollment growth, advocates stress that long-term, stable funding is needed to prevent cuts amid inflation and rising food costs.
title: White House says it will use tariff revenue to fund federal food aid for mothers and young children
